title: Mum hits back at claims entering daughters, 4 and 6, in beauty contest is 'disgusting'
text:

As I watched a row of girls in frilly dresses curtsey in front of a panel of judges, I did a double take.

I’d always thought child pageants were like the TV show Toddlers and Tiaras, with lashings of glitter and fake tan.

But here I was watching my daughters take part, and it was nothing like I thought it would be.

Despite being a mum of two girls, Erin and Efa, ours wasn’t a very girly household.

My husband Chris and I run a martial arts academy so the girls were more at home practising karate than dressing up.

But in 2013, when Efa was four, one of my students told me about the Carnival Queen competition in our hometown of Caernarfon, North Wales.

(Image: Daily Post Wales)

“Your Efa is such a little star she would love it,” she said.

She was right about Efa’s bubbly personality. When she walks into a room she has a real sparkle.

When I mentioned it to Erin, then six, and Efa, they were keen. We borrowed dresses from a friend and went along.

Chris and I watched and were delighted when Efa was crowned Miss Petal, and Erin was a runner up.

Both girls loved it so when we heard about another contest, we entered. It was the Mini Miss European Wales pageant.

There, the girls would be judged on their catwalk, confidence and personality.

The rules ban make-up and fake tan. This was about the contestants showing off their catwalk and personality on stage.

When Efa came first runner-up and won a tiara and sash, we were all cheering like crazy. Next came The Face of The Globe Pageant in Llanelli in September 2015.

It had a proper catwalk and required contestants to raise money for charity beforehand. The girls cleared out their old toys and clothes and raised £700.

Efa wore a pink calf-length dress and Erin wore purple. The judges had a chat with each girl behind the scenes and scored them on that, how much money they had raised, and how they looked on the catwalk.

Efa won her category and Erin won the ­congeniality award – voted for by the other girls. I was so proud, as was Chris. But when I posted my delight on Facebook , not everyone was happy.

“This is disgusting,” one person wrote.

“You’re putting your daughter on stage to be judged on beauty.”

I was furious. “It’s not just about beauty,” I explained. “The girls are learning from the experience.” Now I hope people step back before making a judgement.

It’s not about one girl being ­prettier than another. I wouldn’t put my girls forward for that.

Efa is truly hooked. She won Mini Miss European Wales in 2016.

And when one of her friends told her the winner of Young European Miss International won a trip to the US, she begged to enter.

She needed three different outfits and in total I spent over £400.

When she was announced as the winner I couldn’t hold back the tears. Next stop for us would be Houston, Texas.

I spent two months sewing 150 daffodils onto a yellow gown. Efa had her hair done and was allowed to wear make-up and paint her nails. All in all I spent about £1,000.

She was asked to describe herself in three words. With a cheeky smile, she replied: “Bubbly, because I like making people laugh. Charming, I’m polite and well-mannered. And caring, because if I see someone upset I’ll be first to cheer them up.”

To our delight, she won.

When we got home she couldn’t wait to take her crown to show her friends. Efa told me she wants to win Miss World when she’s 18.

I know some parents might judge me for supporting this, but pageants have taught her many life lessons.

Pageants aren’t just about looks, they’re about building confidence and social skills and teaching girls to be proud of what they can achieve. If becoming Miss World is what she wants, I’ll be there with her.

■■ Follow Gemma and Efa’s story on DRYCH: Tu ôl i’r Tiaras (Behind the Tiaras) on S4C, Sunday, at 9pm.
description: When Gemma Pritchard’s daughter started to enter child beauty pageants, some people were quick to criticise. But Gemma, 38, says the contests are empowering
